content.text: Once upon a time, in a land far away, there lived a poor miller who had a beautiful daughter. The miller was very proud of his daughter, and he loved to boast about her to anyone who would

listen. One day, he went to the king’s palace and told the king, "Your Majesty, I have a daughter who can spin straw into gold!" The king, who loved gold more than anything else in the world, was very
interested. "Is that so?" he said. "Bring her to me at once. If she can truly spin straw into gold, I will make her my queen. But if she cannot, she shall be punished!"
The miller was frightened, but he had no choice. He brought his daughter to the palace, and the king led her to a small room filled with straw. "Here is your task," said the king.
"Spin all this straw into gold by morning, or you will be thrown into the dungeon!" The poor girl was terrified. She had no idea how to spin straw into gold—her father had only been boasting!
She sat down on the floor and began to cry. Suddenly, the door creaked open, and a strange little man with a long, pointed beard hopped into the room.
"Good evening, my dear," he said in a squeaky voice. "Why are you crying?" The girl told him about the king’s demand and her father’s boast. The little man smiled.
"I can help you," he said, "but what will you give me in return?" The girl had nothing but the clothes on her back. "I will give you my necklace," she said.
The little man took the necklace and sat down at the spinning wheel. Whirr, whirr, whirr! The wheel spun faster and faster, and before the girl’s eyes, the straw turned into gleaming gold.
By morning, the room was filled with shining threads. When the king saw the gold, he was delighted—but his greed grew even stronger. He led the girl to a larger room filled with even more straw.
"Spin this into gold by morning," he said, "and I will marry you. But if you fail, you will lose your head!" The girl was even more frightened now. She sat down and began to weep.
Once again, the little man appeared. "What will you give me this time?" he asked. The girl had only one thing left. "I will give you my ring," she said. The little man took the ring and set to work.
Whirr, whirr, whirr! The straw turned to gold once more, and by morning, the room was filled with riches. The king was overjoyed.
But instead of keeping his promise, he took the girl to an even larger room, piled high with straw. "Spin this into gold," he said, "and you shall be my queen.
But if you fail, you will never see the light of day again!" The girl knew she had nothing left to give the little man. She fell to the floor and sobbed. The little man appeared again.
"What will you give me if I spin this straw into gold?" he asked. The girl had no more possessions. "I have nothing left," she said. The little man grinned.
"Then promise me your firstborn child when you are queen." The girl was desperate. She agreed, and the little man spun the straw into gold one last time.
The king, true to his word, married her, and she became queen. A year passed, and the queen gave birth to a beautiful baby boy.
She had almost forgotten about her promise to the little man—until one day, he appeared in her chamber. "Now, my dear," he said, "give me what you promised." The queen was horrified.
She offered him all the gold in the kingdom if he would leave her child alone. But the little man refused. "No," he said. "A promise is a promise." The queen began to cry.
The little man took pity on her. "Very well," he said. "I will give you three days. If by the end of the third day you can guess my name, you may keep your child."
The queen sent messengers all over the kingdom to find unusual names. They returned with lists of strange and funny names—Caspar, Melchior, Balthazar—but none were correct.
On the third day, a messenger returned with an odd tale. He had seen a strange little man dancing around a fire in the woods, singing: *"Tonight, tonight, my plans I make, Tomorrow, tomorrow, the
baby I take. The queen may guess, but here’s the jest— She’ll never, ever guess my name is Rumpelstiltskin!"* The queen was overjoyed. That night, the little man returned to her chamber.
"Now, my queen," he said, "what is my name?" The queen pretended to think. "Is it John?" she asked. "No!" he cried. "Is it Michael?" she asked. "No!" he shouted, stamping his foot.

"Then perhaps," said the queen, "it is Rumpelstiltskin?" The little man shrieked in anger. "The devil told you! The devil told you!" he cried. Then, in a fit of rage, he stamped his foot so hard that it sank
into the floor, and he tore himself in two. The queen kept her child, and the king and queen lived happily ever after.
